questions.text: According to the WHO, which investigation is included in the diagnosis of TB spine?
questions.solution:
Explanation :
CBNAAT/Xpert MTB-RIF is included in WHO diagnostic algorithms for extrapulmonary TB, including spinal TB, because it is a rapid nucleic acid amplification test that detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance in a few hours, guiding early therapy. It has higher sensitivity than smear in paucibacillary disease and is recommended on tissue/aspirate from the suspected vertebral lesion.

Explanation of other options:
X-ray (Option A): Helpful screening (wedging, end-plate erosion, paradiscal involvement), but not sufficient nor specific; radiographs lag behind pathology.
CT scan (Option B): Excellent for bony detail and guiding biopsy but CT alone is not the WHO-included molecular diagnostic.
Culture and sensitivity (Option D): Definitive but slow (weeks); limited yield in paucibacillary disease. WHO still includes Xpert as part of rapid diagnostic work-up.

Key Takeaways:

WHO endorses Xpert MTB/RIF for extrapulmonary TB, including spine.

Imaging suggests diagnosis; microbiologic/molecular tests confirm and detect resistance.

Culture is the gold standard for drug susceptibility but slow.

choices.text: Used in facial nerve repair
Fibrin glue is used during repair
Anterior interosseous nerve and saphenous nerve used as graft

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nerve grafting?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Autologous nerve grafting (most commonly sural nerve) bridges segmental defectsin peripheral nerves when tension-free end-to-end repair isn't possible. This restores continuity for axonal regeneration. Adjuncts such as fibrin glue may be used but do not replace micro sutures. Donor nerves are usually sensory (sural, medial/lateral antebrachial cutaneous)

Explanation of other options:
Used in facial nerve repair (Option B): True in principle (interposition/cable grafts may be used). Not the single best answer vs A, which states the core indication across orthopaedics.
Fibrin glue is used during repair (Option C): Adjunctively true-fibrin glue can reinforce coaptation but does not replace micro sutures; selection depends on surgeon preference.
Anterior interosseous nerve and saphenous nerve used as graft (Option D): Incorrect. Typical donor grafts are sural, medial antebrachial cutaneous, lateral antebrachial cutaneous. AIN is a motor branch (used as a donor nerve for transfers, not as a free graft). 'Saphenous' generally refers to a vein used as a conduit, not the nerve as a standard graft.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for an intertrochanteric fracture in a 72-year-old female?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Stable or unstable intertrochanteric fractures in the elderly are commonly managed with cephalomedullary (intramedullary) nails due to better load-sharing, less varus collapse, and earlier mobilization compared with plate devices. Arthroplasty is reserved for specific scenarios (non-reconstructible head/neck, severe comminution with osteoarthritis, salvage).

Explanation of other options:
Hemiarthroplasty (Option A): Considered in select unstable IT patterns with poor bone/failed fixation-but not first-line for typical IT fractures.
ORIF with plating (DHS/plate) (Option C): Acceptable in stable patterns but IM nails favoured for unstable and many standard patterns due to biomechanics.
Boot and bar (Option D): Obsolete/inappropriate for modern IT fracture care; leads to complications of recumbency.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is very rarely involved in chronic osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
'Chronic osteomyelitis' in orthopaedic sense typically refers to chronic pyogenic infection-most commonly Staphylococcus aureus, but other pyogenic organisms (including streptococci and gram-negative bacilli like E. coli and Klebsiella) do occur. Tuberculous osteomyelitis is a granulomatous process and is classified separately from chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis, hence 'very rarely' listed under chronic pyogenic causes.

Explanation of other options:
Streptococcus (Option A): Recognized pyogenic pathogen in chronic osteomyelitis.
E. coli (Option B): Gram-negative organism-seen in chronic/post-operative cases.
Klebsiella (Option C): Gram-negative-documented in chronic osteomyelitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pyogenicchronic osteomyelitis ≠ tuberculous bone disease.
  • Gram-positives and gram-negatives both implicated in chronic pyogenic infections.

questions.text: Which tumour is associated with Codman’s triangle and sunburst appearance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Osteosarcoma classically shows aggressive periosteal reaction with Codman's triangle (periosteum lifted creating an angle) and a sunburst pattern of spiculated new bone radiating from the cortex.

Explanation of other options:
Ewing's (Option B): Onion-skin/lamellated periosteal reaction more typical.
GCT (Option C):Eccentric, expansile lytic lesion at epiphysis; lacks sunburst/Codman's.
Chondrosarcoma (Option D): Rings-and-arcs calcification, endosteal scalloping-not classic sunburst.

choices.text: Thumb-spica cast and follow-up after 10-14 days

questions.text: A laborer falls on an outstretched hand and has anatomical snuffbox tenderness. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
When radiographs are normal but snuffbox tenderness is present (high clinical suspicion), MRI is the most sensitive early test to detect occult scaphoid fractures and to assess vascularity.

If MRI is not available immediately, the accepted alternative is immobilized in a thumb-spica cast and repeat radiographs (or MRI) in 10-14 days (Option C ruled out). CT helps show fracture lines and assess displacement/unions but is less sensitive than MRI for early detection.

Explanation of other options:
NSAIDs & discharge (Option A): Unsafe-risk of missed scaphoid fracture → non-union/AVN.

Thumb-spica cast and follow-up after 10-14 days (Option C): Acceptable alternative if MRI not promptly available; classic teaching.

CT scan (Option D): Good for fracture line characterization and union assessment; less sensitive than MRI for occult injury/vascularity.

Flowchart-Suspected Scaphoid, normal X-ray

Suspected scaphoid (snuffbox tender) →

  1. If MRI available now → MRI→

(+) fracture ⇒ immobilize/operate as indicated; (-) ⇒ mobilize.

  1. If MRI not available →

Thumb-spica → Repeat X-ray +/- MRI at 10-14 days.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis presents with neck pain and signs of myelopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Rheumatoid arthritis commonly affects the cervical spine at C1-C2 (atlantoaxial joint) with transverse ligament laxity and/or erosion of odontoid, leading to anterior atlantoaxial subluxation and potential spinal cord compression/myelopathy.

Explanation of other options:
OA (Option A): Degenerative, less typical in RA myelopathy presentation.
C2-C3 stenosis (Option B): RA classically targets C1-C2.
Disc herniation (Option D): Possible but less characteristic of RA-related myelopathy than C1-C2 instability.

questions.text: The Honda sign on the short tau inversion recovery (STIR) MRI is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:
The 'Honda' (H-shaped) uptake or Edema pattern across the sacrum (vertical alar lines with a transverse component) on bone scan or MRI STIR is characteristic of bilateral vertical sacral insufficiency fractures (osteoporotic).

Explanation of other options:
Transient marrow Edema (Option A) Non-specific; lacks characteristic H-pattern.
Acute osteomyelitis (Option B): shows marrow Edema but no H-configuration.
Multiple myeloma (Option D): focal/diffuse lesions; not the classic Honda pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors in childhood cannot be associated with lytic bone lesions and pain while walking?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Ewing's is classically lytic/destructive. Neuroblastoma and retinoblastoma can metastasize to bone with lytic lesions and bony pain. In childhood, clear-cell renal cell carcinoma metastasis to bone is exceptionally uncommon; pediatric renal tumors with bone tropism are more typically clear-cell sarcoma of the kidney, not RCC. Hence Option D is the best exclusion here.

Explanation of other options:
Metastatic retinoblastoma (Option A): Can produce lytic bone metastases with pain.
Ewing's sarcoma (Option B): Aggressive lytic lesion with permeative destruction.
Metastatic neuroblastoma (Option C): Frequently involves bone/bone marrow with lytic lesions and gait pain/limping.

Key Takeaways:

  • Most pediatric malignant bone processes listed (A-C) can be lytic.
  • Pediatric RCCbone metastasis is rare; don't confuse it with clear-cell sarcoma of kidney.
